body.p: When you evaluate Smalltalk code in a Workspace or Accept a method in a browser, the Source Code Editor may notify you of an error using red-highlighted text. The error message appears directly beneath the line of code in which the error was found, and disappears automatically when the issue has been resolved.
There are only a few types of errors, most of which can be easily corrected.

variablesundeclared errorerrorsundeclared variableIf you neglect to declare a variable in a method definition and select Accept to compile it, the Source Code Editor prompts you with a list of variable types. By picking an item from this list, you may declare the variable as a temporary, instance, shared, or name space variable. Finally, you also have the option to add the variable to the Undeclared List.
errorsnothing more expectedThis error usually occurs if you have omitted a period as the end of a message expression.

missing source codesource codemissingSource code is stored in a single sources file associated with your ∏ development image. Very rarely, if you have improperly moved your development image and/or sources files on your workstation's file system, you may receive an alert that source files cannot be found.
If you see code in the browser with a comment explaining that it is decompiled code, the system source or changes file is not correctly identified with your image.

To correctly identify the sources file, open the Settings Tool (select System → Settings in the Launcher window) and check that the ∏ Home Directory (on the System tab) is correct. If the missing source code error persists, it may be necessary to edit the Source → Source Files page, making sure the prefix of the ".sou" file agrees with the name of your saved image file (e.g., visual.im expects to find sources in visual.sou).
